data.title: [themes] Should the default theme be applied when a theme is active?
data.body:
Playing around with making themes for the first time and I'm finding it a little frustrating how my styles are being overridden by the default theme due to having a lower CSS specificity. Was this intentional or am I doing it wrong? Seems like theme development would be a lot nicer if I could be as general as I wanted.

data.title: Not opening anymore
data.body:
The VSCode on my machine stopped to open from one day to another, without updating VSCode.

**A JavaScript error occurred in the main process**

```
Uncaught Exception:
Error: watch ENOSPC
    at exports._errnoException (util.js:837:11)
    at FSWatcher.start (fs.js:1247:11)
    at Object.fs.watch (fs.js:1273:11)
    at t.e.registerWatchers (/home/fgodoy/bin/VSCode-linux-x64/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-main/main.js:7:18607)
    at t.e (/home/fgodoy/bin/VSCode-linux-x64/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-main/main.js:7:17858)
    at new t (/home/fgodoy/bin/VSCode-linux-x64/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-main/main.js:7:20553)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/home/fgodoy/bin/VSCode-linux-x64/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-main/main.js:7:20864)
    at e._invokeFactory (/home/fgodoy/bin/VSCode-linux-x64/resources/app/out/vs/loader.js:4:13773)
    at e._complete (/home/fgodoy/bin/VSCode-linux-x64/resources/app/out/vs/loader.js:4:14012)
    at e.resolveDependency (/home/fgodoy/bin/VSCode-linux-x64/resources/app/out/vs/loader.js:4:15066)
```

data.title: TextLine.firstNonWhitespaceCharacterIndex
data.body:
Definition is "The offset of the first character which is not a whitespace character as defined by /\s/"

It may now be too late to change, but I found it weird that for empty or whitespace-only lines, <s>`0`</s> the length of the string is returned. `0` implies that there _is_ a non-whitespace character at position 0, whereas in fact there is no non-whitespace character. Therefore I'd expect the value returned in this case to be `-1` or something.

If it has to stay that way then there should really be a note in the docs I guess.

**Edit:** I had it slightly wrong first time: for empty lines, it returns 0, but for lines with whitespace chars it returns the length of the string. Sure I can see the logic, though I still think it's not the value people would expect (and `leadingWhitespaceLength` would then have been a more appropriate name).

data.title: Update to Electron 0.37.x
data.body:
Fixes the following issues:
- Linux: Button order in dialogs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1297
- Mac: Storage flush on update: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/172
- Show the application window as soon as possible: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/163

Might have impact on following issues on blurriness:
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1896
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1334
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/254
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/959

**Updates:**
- Chrome from 45 to 49
- node.js from 4.1.1 to 5.10.0
- libuv from 1.7.4 to 1.8.0

data.title: Feature Requests: Add command/button to git branch delete (local and remote)
Inconsistent out structure when no test folder is available
data.body:
When I build a extension with test folder the out folder is structured as (other files/folders removed for clarification)

```
out/
    src/
        extension.ts
    test/
        index.ts
```

but, without the test folder the out folder is structured as

```
out/
    extension.ts
```

Which leads the extension to fail the activation process. Because in the `package.json` there is a directive ("main") that tells that the `extension.js` is in `./out/src/extension`
## Steps to reproduce

In the command line 

```
1. yo code
2. cd into the extension directory
3. Choose New extension (TypeScript)
4. npm run vscode:prepublish 
5. ls out
6. Inspect the output
```

```
1. yo code
2. cd into the extension directory
3. Choose New extension (TypeScript)
4. rm -rf test
5. npm run vscode:prepublish
6. ls out
7. Inspect the output
```

In my opinion it shoud output the structure  below

```
out/
    src/
        extension.ts
```

data.title: without --nolazy option breakpoints are jumping to line in generated source
data.body:
...instead of staying on line in original source.

The bug behind this is not a new issue, but it was uncovered by the removal of the "--nolazy" option.

data.title: Trouble with editor.action.format
data.body:
##### Summary

I am unable to format code for `xml` and `c#`.  `json` and `javascript` do not have any issues.
##### What I have done

Originally I modified my `editor.tabSize` to be 2 (in workspace).  I removed this override and just left in the defaults.  I also overwrote the keybinding for `editor.action.format` to use `ctrl+k ctrl+d`.  I also removed those and left just the default in.  Working with test files of each type mentioned above I am able to format some file types, but not others.  This does not seem to be dependent on any of my settings, I have just added that information in just in case it is relevant.
##### C# example - what I expect

The following screenshot the brackets should line up in MyClass.  

In this case while the tab size is set to 2 I would also expect that `MyClass` would be moved left to adjust to the correct tab size.

Officially the starting bracket would be on the same line as the class definition for my company policy, but I do not see that option available.  Bonus points if you can mention how to set this in `VSCode`. `VS Enterprise` was able to do this with just a checkbox in settings, I am ok with a bool in json, I just do not see the value anywhere.  

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4823412/12682728/4263c060-c672-11e5-9958-4dd9f3aa1900.png)
##### XML example - what I expect

Here I expect that `subLevel3` would be tabbed in to whatever the current tab setting is.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4823412/12682872/0b85cc90-c673-11e5-8e65-b870065e79d8.png)
##### Tech Specs

Windows 10 Pro
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4823412/12682585/71c74e0e-c671-11e5-97c0-46db54335eea.png)

data.title: Breakpoints not hit when debugging NodeJS via Launch
data.body:
The breakpoints seem to register with Node as the breakpoint indicator circle is red-filled. With `stopOnEntry` enabled, the stop does occur, but no breakpoints beyond that are hit.

I'm on OS 10.11.2, VS Code v0.10.6, Node v4.2.3 and my launch.json is:

```
  ...
  "configurations": [{
    "type": "node",
    "request": "launch",
    "program": "bin/www",
    "name": "Launch",
    "outDir": null,
    "externalConsole": true
  } ...
```

data.title: Debugger isn't showing TypeScript source

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
In a TypeScript project the VS Code debugger displays the generated JavaScript code instead of the TypeScript code:

![vscode debugger no typescript](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9283914/12677669/e05d070e-c69a-11e5-9aed-21727a4a6fd1.png)

What's wrong?

Shouldn't the IDE better emit a warning when it can't find the corresponding map referenced in a file and provide a list of locations to the user listing where it's unsuccessfully been searching for the original source?

See this sample repository for a reference: [SetTrend/TS18N](https://github.com/SetTrend/TS18N).
